componenttextpreview: One question I had is that you talked about the plan with the PPA assets to engage in a parallel path strategic review or reregulation. Is it possible that, that strategic review could somehow be folded into the ongoing process around the non-PPA assets?
componenttext: One question I had is that you talked about the plan with the PPA assets to engage in a parallel path strategic review or reregulation. Is it possible that, that strategic review could somehow be folded into the ongoing process around the non-PPA assets? Or do you see these as definitely sort of separate track?

headline: American Electric Power Co., Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're going to start the process, obviously, with the PPA assets. We don't want to slow down the other assets. So we're still looking at that to see what can be done to address it. But we don't want to slow down the existing process going on. We're g
componenttext: Yes, we're going to start the process, obviously, with the PPA assets. We don't want to slow down the other assets. So we're still looking at that to see what can be done to address it. But we don't want to slow down the existing process going on. We're going to stay on schedule and we're going to continue cranking away and then we'll initiate the process. And actually, initiating a process on the PPA assets is relatively easy to do because we've already done it for the non-PPA assets. So it can move along relatively quickly as well. The question is, I mean, to roll, all of a sudden, roll it in to the existing process, it may be challenging. We'll just have to take a look at that.

headline: American Electric Power Co., Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just to clarify, on timing. I think, Nick, in your remarks, you said you'd hope to have a sort of process fully wrapped up for the non-PPA assets by the end of the year. I think -- and I think maybe I heard Brian say you'd update us on the third
componenttext: And then just to clarify, on timing. I think, Nick, in your remarks, you said you'd hope to have a sort of process fully wrapped up for the non-PPA assets by the end of the year. I think -- and I think maybe I heard Brian say you'd update us on the third quarter. So is that the -- is that kind of the -- is there a possibility that year-end is the outside date and things happen quicker?

headline: American Electric Power Co., Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, obviously, we would want an announcement in the third quarter and then we'd want to close as quickly as we can and we've been able to close transactions relatively quickly before and it's a known set of assets. So we feel like it may be aggr
componenttext: Yes, I think, obviously, we would want an announcement in the third quarter and then we'd want to close as quickly as we can and we've been able to close transactions relatively quickly before and it's a known set of assets. So we feel like it may be aggressive, but we want to close by the end of the year.

headline: American Electric Power Co., Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So can you share when bids are due or anything like that?
componenttext: So can you share when bids are due or anything like that?

headline: American Electric Power Co., Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have initial bids in a cycle that I think occurs during the second quarter, and then the third quarter will be final bids.
componenttext: Well, we have initial bids in a cycle that I think occurs during the second quarter, and then the third quarter will be final bids.

headline: American Electric Power Co., Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then can I just -- the other part of the parallel path. What would be -- where are you on this reregulation proposal? Is it good standing start? Or is there some momentum kind of in the background? We've obviously just heard the Chairman
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then can I just -- the other part of the parallel path. What would be -- where are you on this reregulation proposal? Is it good standing start? Or is there some momentum kind of in the background? We've obviously just heard the Chairman of the PUC step off the stairs, or about to. Can you just update us on how you see that? And how likely it is that something could really materialize faster than a strategic review?

headline: American Electric Power Co., Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'll just probably make a distinction because even before we started the PPA, I said the State of Ohio needed to decide. But I also said that the commission needs to decide. And because we were trying to do something within the purview of the existin
componenttext: Yes. I'll just probably make a distinction because even before we started the PPA, I said the State of Ohio needed to decide. But I also said that the commission needs to decide. And because we were trying to do something within the purview of the existing legislation, and it had been left up to the deference of the commission to decide. In this case, we're not talking about the commission. Now obviously, we'd love for the commission to be part of that process. They need to be part of the process. But this is a legislative issue. And our concern is, and I think there has to be a broader concern by the State of Ohio, and that's represented by the legislature. What do we do to enable Ohio to take a firm hold of the capacity and energy situation within the state, the development of new resources, the jobs, taxes, and all those things that we talked about earlier. And I don't -- it's not like you're starting at ground zero to do this. I think the issues in Ohio are well-known from an energy policy perspective. Matter fact, we just got through with a review through the Ohio Business Roundtable. The Columbus Partnership has been involved. There is definitely already steps being taken. It's a question of okay, what steps? And there, you're talking about okay, is there a stopgap measure to basically allow the transfer of certain assets within the State of Ohio to AEP Ohio directly and avoid a -- any kind of affiliate transaction? Which probably is, I would say, is probably a better chance of accomplishing something like that than full reregulation. But I wouldn't take that off the table either. I mean, because I think there's broader issues that are involved here. Like for instance, if Ohio wants to move forward with renewables and renewable implementation and balance out the portfolio and focus on natural gas, those are clearly areas that can fall within some form of reregulation.

headline: American Electric Power Co., Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Would a transfer, like you suggest, require a FERC approval?
componenttext: Would a transfer, like you suggest, require a FERC approval?

headline: American Electric Power Co., Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. But that kind of approval, they've already done before. We already did it for net book transfers from our Ohio -- what was our Ohio fleet, to other jurisdictions, and they were approved without a hitch. So I think there's probably plenty of precedenc
componenttext: Yes. But that kind of approval, they've already done before. We already did it for net book transfers from our Ohio -- what was our Ohio fleet, to other jurisdictions, and they were approved without a hitch. So I think there's probably plenty of precedence on that one.

headline: American Electric Power Co., Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to the line of Michael Weinstein with UBS.
componenttext: We'll go next to the line of Michael Weinstein with UBS.

headline: American Electric Power Co., Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the case of, let's say, total reregulation, is the Ohio fleet enough to serve returning load, let's say? I mean, I'm thinking about the overall -- a much larger implication that, that might entail for the utility. Or do you have to build additional gen
componenttext: In the case of, let's say, total reregulation, is the Ohio fleet enough to serve returning load, let's say? I mean, I'm thinking about the overall -- a much larger implication that, that might entail for the utility. Or do you have to build additional generation under that kind of a scenario?

headline: American Electric Power Co., Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the first answer is no, there's not enough. Secondly, we'd have to deal with the capacity deficiency either through the market or building new capacity. And I think it's a perfect opportunity for the State of Ohio to look at natural gas and renewables
componenttext: So the first answer is no, there's not enough. Secondly, we'd have to deal with the capacity deficiency either through the market or building new capacity. And I think it's a perfect opportunity for the State of Ohio to look at natural gas and renewables to fill out that approach. And as long as Ohio has control in doing that kind of thing, then we are ready, willing and able to move that direction.

headline: American Electric Power Co., Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Are there any -- have you already been in touch with members of the legislature to begin the process at this point? Or is this basically an initial reaction off last night's news?
componenttext: Are there any -- have you already been in touch with members of the legislature to begin the process at this point? Or is this basically an initial reaction off last night's news?

headline: American Electric Power Co., Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not going to address that. I think, certainly, people are aware of the issues with energy policy in Ohio. And there have been discussions relative to the PPA with legislators and they're fully aware of what the issues are. And it's not a huge stretch
componenttext: I'm not going to address that. I think, certainly, people are aware of the issues with energy policy in Ohio. And there have been discussions relative to the PPA with legislators and they're fully aware of what the issues are. And it's not a huge stretch for them to ask the question, well, why don't we just reregulate?

headline: American Electric Power Co., Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And is -- would it be more accurate to say this is more like a 3-track process where you would go? Reregulation is track 1 and track 2 might be transferring plants into rate base? Yes, and I guess instead of -- and third is to sell the plants right throug
componenttext: And is -- would it be more accurate to say this is more like a 3-track process where you would go? Reregulation is track 1 and track 2 might be transferring plants into rate base? Yes, and I guess instead of -- and third is to sell the plants right through another process, right?

headline: American Electric Power Co., Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we have to look at and probably do have to have discussions about what is the most expedient process. Because, I mean, there are several options here that we can't talk about. And some of them may be stopgap, some of them may be longer term. So I
componenttext: I think we have to look at and probably do have to have discussions about what is the most expedient process. Because, I mean, there are several options here that we can't talk about. And some of them may be stopgap, some of them may be longer term. So I think -- and certainly, I think that others in the state will agree that we need to respond quickly from -- to enable us to continue to do what Ohio wants us to do with that generation. And so I'd say, we are obviously discussing several options internally among ourselves, but we haven't gone out with specific policy objectives, at least, detailed objectives on how we want to approach it. Because obviously, we want to do what's the most expeditious way to do it. Because in my book, I mean, the race is on. The race is on between our option of the strategic evaluation versus our option to have some form of reregulation coverage. And maybe a misnomer to call it reregulation, but we'll have to see what that means. And -- but I'm -- I think AEP has reached the point where it's time to get this resolved once and for all.

componenttext: Yes, so from a Louisiana perspective, I think it's really taken a step out there to start to deal with it, the phantom tax issue. headline: American Electric Power Co., Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to focus on the core business actually. And looking at Slide 4, are we seeing degradation? If I were to look at the same slide for the last year or so, are you seeing some degradation? I mean I'll use a handful of examples, PSO, AEP Texas, SWEPCO,
componenttext: I want to focus on the core business actually. And looking at Slide 4, are we seeing degradation? If I were to look at the same slide for the last year or so, are you seeing some degradation? I mean I'll use a handful of examples, PSO, AEP Texas, SWEPCO, pretty big subsidiaries, numbers up here potentially heading the wrong direction or have headed the wrong direction there. Can you give a little more detail about the dollar rate increase request at SWEPCO and AEP Texas? When you expect those to go in? And what kind of impact you have that -- you expect that to have on regulated returns in both markets?

headline: American Electric Power Co., Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me start with Texas first. TCC and TNC, we recently filed the distribution and cost recovery factors there. And those requests are TCC, about $54 million; TNC, about $16 million. In terms of when we expect them to come in place, the proposed effective
componenttext: Let me start with Texas first. TCC and TNC, we recently filed the distribution and cost recovery factors there. And those requests are TCC, about $54 million; TNC, about $16 million. In terms of when we expect them to come in place, the proposed effective date for both of those is September 1 of this year. And so the effect of those increases will come in, in this chart, over the course of the following 12 months in that regard. In SWEPCO, we also have a Texas TCRF that's in. And we've requested an increase of about $4.9 million, very small average customer increase. In addition, we've had a SWEPCO distribution cost recovery factor where we've requested another about $9.2 million. So very much trying to take advantage of the relatively quick recovery mechanisms that they have with the cost recovery filings that are short of a full rate case in Texas and trying to get those increases reflected as quickly as possible to help get some of those Texas and SWEPCO ROEs moving in the right direction. In PSO, we've implemented a rate increase effective January 1 of this year subject to refund and are expecting an order out of the Oklahoma commission sometime this quarter. And again, that should have that PSO ROE moving in the right direction up closer to the upper 9s, closer to 10% range.

headline: American Electric Power Co., Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And keep in mind, Michael, some of this is deliberate, too. I mean block transmission, for example, I mean we're spending a lot of money there and obviously, there's a great recovery mechanism. But we're still chasing the recovery mechanism because we're
componenttext: And keep in mind, Michael, some of this is deliberate, too. I mean block transmission, for example, I mean we're spending a lot of money there and obviously, there's a great recovery mechanism. But we're still chasing the recovery mechanism because we're investing so much. And the other jurisdictions, we are filing rate cases to catch up in certain areas. But all in all, I mean we look at it like we're managing these across the board. So some may be see -- you're seeing drop a little bit but there may be specific reasons for that, that we -- that we're investing or that we expect rate-making aspects to come around at some point. But we're making very deliberate choices. And even during the first quarter, I mean, we didn't cut back on our planned O&M or any of those activities because it's the first quarter. Generally, you'd have to say that, yes, probably if you looked at it 2 years ago, we were probably at 10.3% that we estimated for the year and -- but you're still in that 10% area. So -- and that's where we try to manage this thing to ensure that we're meeting that threshold across-the-board. So I wouldn't be looking at SWEPCO, for example, and saying, "Well, that's the general trend for everyone." We've talked about the specific issue at SWEPCO and it's that Turk piece, the 88 megawatts of Arkansas that we really need to resolve. But timing is going to be an issue there.

headline: American Electric Power Co., Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The equalizer chart that you referred to on Slide 4, Michael, is very much a heads-up display for us. And when we see those lower ROEs, we are either taking action or have taken action to try and get those improved. And you see that across-the-board whene
componenttext: The equalizer chart that you referred to on Slide 4, Michael, is very much a heads-up display for us. And when we see those lower ROEs, we are either taking action or have taken action to try and get those improved. And you see that across-the-board whenever you see those bubbles or balls there, whatever you want to call them, getting in the lower end of the range.

componenttext: Got it. Okay. I want to follow up, and I know it's a small subsidiary for you. headline: American Electric Power Co., Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Yes, so in Kentucky, we're likely to be making another filing. So when that occurs, you'll continue to see that improvement as well. So there are some benefits of being in the Kentucky jurisdiction. But you have to look at this thing in the overall context. It is a small bubble. But it's one that's on the uptick from an ROE perspective and will continue progressing that way.

With the other set of assets, I'm sure -- we've got to get a lot of data and information together for them to present them in a positive way to ensure that potential investors can look at those assets and give them time to do that. So I don't -- we wouldn't want to slow down the non-PPA -- the existing non-PPA for that. And you can only move so quickly with those kinds of transactions, particularly when -- as it relates to the existing PPA assets. So -- but we'll start the process. We'll move as quickly as we can. I'm just trying to be realistic in that it will take a little bit longer than the existing schedule we have for the non-PPA. And -- now, what it also says is that the reregulation or anything, any potential option thereof, is going to have to move very aggressively. And so we don't have any time to spare on that because I think that -- but I'm just saying that that's not the critical path. On the critical path, we have 2 projects. One, existing non-PPA. And then now we have the existing PPA assets. And we're going to move as quickly as we can. There's been a lot of homework done on it. A lot of analysis done on it. So we don't have to do any of that and recreate it. But we've got to make sure the process is robust enough so that people can understand probably a more complex set of resources.

But a more fulsome discussion on what we would do with use of proceeds would likely be at an Analyst Day following the announcement of the resolution of that strategic review.

componenttext: What I can tell you is we're very mindful of, is that we have a whole laundry list of potential places to put any available cash that comes in. Not only operating companies but also on the competitor side with Purchase Power Arrangement. So those are opportunities that we can continue to develop in anticipation of cash proceeds coming in. But what I want to make sure of is that we're not going to just get a pile of cash and have it burn a hole in our pocket  and we wind up doing something stupid.

componenttext: Yes, I think, certainly, Senator Murkowski has been working very hard to get bipartisan support for the bill, has energy efficiency provisions, has provisions for the grid, in terms of certainly the focus on making sure the grid is reliable. I think that's a good bill. And obviously, it has to go to conference and Fred Upton has been working on the other side, on the House side, so they'll have to put those 2 together. So -- and they're very different in some respect. So we'll have to work through that process. But overall though, anything that Congress and the Senate can do to come together from a bipartisan standpoint to focus on reliability of the grid, integration of all these activities that we're having to deal with is a good thing. And I think it's a good start. Now there's some heavier lift issues that eventually will need to be addressed. But you've got to start somewhere. And I think Lisa Murkowski has done an incredible job. I think it's Cantwell on the other side, on the other side of the aisle also. But it's good to see.

componenttext: Yes, well, so we haven't neither created nor destroyed capacity out in the market. So there may have to be interim solutions of capacity to get through until the state can actually decide what does an integrated resource plan look like for the state going forward? So the capacity is probably available so -- but because we transferred out-capacity as well, we'll need to -- and retired capacity, we'll need to make sure we have a plan to recover from that. I think from the customer standpoint, to put new capacity in place or buy existing capacity that's out on the market would be a positive thing to provide certainty in terms of their bills in the future. And I just see a very volatile future for Ohio customers and usually, that volatility happens at bad times where customers can ill afford to be able to pay a bill. I think we sort of -- the utility sort of focus, particularly in integrated utility, is sort of a big budget biller. And when you open it up to the market forces, the budget biller is not in the game anymore. So I think there's value in that.

headline: American Electric Power Co., Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you  Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call for American Electric Power. We are glad that you are able to join us today. Our earnings release, presentation slides and related financial information are available
componenttext:
Thank you  Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call for American Electric Power. We are glad that you are able to join us today. Our earnings release, presentation slides and related financial information are available on our website at aep.com. Today, we will be making forward-looking statements during the call. There are many factors that may cause future results to differ materially from these statements. Please refer to SEC filings for discussion of these factors. 
Joining me this morning for opening remarks are Nick Akins, our Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Brian Tierney, our Chief Financial Officer. We will take your questions following their remarks. 
I'll now turn the call over to Nick.

headline: American Electric Power Co., Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, thank you, once again, joining AEP's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. AEP had a strong second quarter with GAAP in operating earnings coming in at $1.2 per share  and $095 per share respectively. Bringing the year-to-date earning
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, thank you, once again, joining AEP's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. AEP had a strong second quarter with GAAP in operating earnings coming in at $1.2 per share  and $095 per share respectively. Bringing the year-to-date earnings to $2 04 per share on a GAAP basis and a $1.97 per share on an operating basis. This compares favorably to the second quarter 2015 GAAP in operating earnings of $0.88 per share. The 2016 year-to-date earnings compared unfavorably to 2015 primarily June by the significant energy and different experienced in the first quarter of 2015 versus first quarter 2016 as we reported last quarter. These results clearly, keep some pace to meet our operating earnings guidance range of $3.60 to $3.80 per share, which we are reaffirming. We are also reaffirming our 4% to 6% growth rate. So overall goes quarter for the disciplined and consistency there are investors can be expect from AEP. 
Our focus on the Utility Operations, transmission growth, expansion of our customer sales channels, process optimization and the disciplined deployment of capital and O&M expenses continues to drive positive results for our shareholders and the customers. While externally it may appear to be relatively calm quarter there has been substantial activity internally therefore the demonstrates the direction of AEP and strategy to the next premium regulated utility. 
We recently established a chief customer officer assumed by, our former AEP Texas President that provides focus on improving our customer experience. This organization redesign will focus on addressing the evolving between regulatory framework, emerging technologies that enhance the customer experience and deploying the analytics and technology into the future to address resource needs and to optimize smart grid applications. As we progress with the substantial build-out of transmission and distribution to accommodate large-scale optimization and renewal of the grid along with the development of additional sales channels that provide a growth, we are emerging as an energy company that provides solutions for our customers to both the classical regular did annual up to provides universal access and tailored solutions for customers.
AEP's culture is one-off collaboration and innovation and I have no doubt AEP when focused on investments in the largest transmission system in the U.S. and energy grid of tomorrow will continue to be want to be the next premium regulatory energy company. Also during the second quarter we continued our strategic review with the competitive generation. Keep in mind, we now have 2 branches of generation. The first of which we've called the non-PPA assets for better term, which essentially is the natural gas units and the coal station. The process for this tranche is going according to plan and continues beyond initial bids that we received in the second quarter with final bids due in August. I can say that the response has been robust and we are confident that the process will move toward the conclusion of the strategic review in the coming months.
We've also begun the planning for the disposition of any cash proceeds to ensure an earnings trajectory that replaces whilst earnings as quickly as possible. This could include some ramp-up capital spending in transmission and other actions that we've done previously and, because of immediate recognition off PTC benefits, one business we are currently wrapping up is our investment in long-term solar arrangements as well. 
The second tranche, the previously referred to PPA assets are in the initial phase are preparing the assets for process much like the non-PPA assets.
This process will occur in parallel with our focused efforts toward restructuring in Ohio. We will be discussing these issues and implications in more detail during the coming months, leading up to November EER. 
To follow-up on the Ohio restructuring discussion for those of you who don't know, several of our company sites have shown up in the latest One of those sites was our sitting in front of one Riverside corporate headquarters, the virtual reality of Pokmon next to our generator turbine in Ohio may be think that it may be good for a game, but if the generator was virtual, we might have a real problem on our hands and that is where Ohio is heading if it depends too much on federal markets that do not value long-term baseload generation. 
I you to look at PJM website. pjm.com to review the generation mix of the during the warm days we have been experiencing lightly. The vast majority of capacity at the time of the peak is delivered by coal and nuclear resources that are not valued properly market construct.
[Audio Gap]
same generation in the state and the customer's ability to choose generation suppliers. This overall process would allow AEP Ohio to move forward with the transition of generation resources and responsible way that would benefit the state of Ohio and AEP in its customers. The legislation would address any potential jurisdictional matters, while allowing the state to take control of itt's own resources as well as any transition envision another initiatives such as Clean Power Plan. 
In the absence of restructuring legislation, AEP will continue with the strategic process with the second tranche of generation. We continue to analyze the situation our service territory. Shell gas load is in recent month long mining while industrial load is dropped commercial and residential load increased from quarter-to-quarter but last several years have overall been mix bag in hard to read, much like the economy in general.  Brian, will address the root load related issues in more detail in a few minutes. 
Moving to the equalizer chart on Page 4 that shows our various operating areas. Our overall ROE continues to improve, as we mentioned last quarter, it's now at 9.8% versus 9.4% that we reported last quarter and still expected move towards our forecasted 10.1% overall ROE for 2016.  So all according to plan. So here is the story for each of the regulated business units. For Ohio Power, the ROE for AEP Ohio is at the end of the second quarter was 13.3%. We expect to be more favorable than the forecast of 11.9% at the end of the year. The improved ROE forecast is primarily due to AEP Ohio receiving regulatory order related to the recovery that allows us to recover deferred fuel costs with caring charges as approved by the commission ESP 1 case. 
And also $21 million increase in retail margin due to a regulatory reversal provision that occurred. And then favorable annual PJM transmission formula rate through So all of Ohio Power is doing very well at this point and then we continue to expect that. 
APCo, the increase in ROE primarily due to onetime recognition of deferred billing in West Virginia approved by Public Service Commission of West Virginia in June of 2016. The 2015 West Virginia base rate case included the way of billing of $25 million annual base rate increase to residential customers until July 2016.
As these revenues in the company's ROE is expected to trend nearly 2016 forecasted ROE. APCo does continue to monitor reductions in industrial and residential load, particular in the coal depressed areas of the state. We're watching that very closely. 
Kentucky Power, we are seeing the expected continue improvement at quarter-end, the commission authorized the $45 million rate increase effective July 2015, and this rate case will continue to improve the ROE in 2016. And also they are continuing to watch their economy as well. 
I&M achieved an ROE of 10.1%, I&M continues to benefit from reasonable regulatory frameworks in place for those major capital investments programs that we've had in the state generation such as Rockport, the solar projects, nuclear with the lifecycle management and transmission projects as well. So I&M is well-positioned for another positive year in 2016. PSO, it's ROE is generally aligned with expectations, Oklahoma's economy continues to experience a slowdown due in large part low oil process and reduced oil and gas activity in the state. In December 2015, the Oklahoma Corporation and Commission heard the rate case and PSO implemented an interim base rate increase of $75 million subject to refund in January of 2016. 
So a final commission order is expected on that in the fourth quarter. SWEPCO, 2016 revenues were challenged by the weakness in oil and natural gas process, some wholesale revenues rolling off for sale customers exercise options for cell generation market participation, but we filed an application that went into effect March 24, to recover our retrofit investments at Welsh and Flint Creek. And then in taxes, we filed transmission distribution writers as well in that state. 
So we continue to make a various filings in those states to improve the ROE. AEP Texas, the ongoing distribution capital investment, AEP Texas to serve higher levels of electric load and maintain the reliability of the grid had gradually lower the regulated ROE over time. 
The ROE should continued to improve and however, due to recently approved $36 million settlement that will go into effect September 1, 2016. And that's distribution cost recovery factor, for those of you don't know what is AEP Transmission Holdco the Transmission Holdco's return of 11.7% is outperforming the 2016 forecast of 10.2%. The increase in ROE is really focused on true up an annual true up that occurs in the transmission formula. So we expect that ROE to come down during the year, but still expect to be around 10.7% by year-end. 
So that non-measurable process that we are going to through there. So overall, 9.8% continues to track up upward and we are pleased with the progress that Abu operating companies have made. So overall, another great quarter for AEP. This quarter has been a continued approach by AEP and showed consistency discipline and institution to provide quality shareholder value. It's hard for anyone from outside AEP to see company see from inside, dedication, innovation of approximately 18,000 employees. So I'll just put it this way. I happen to play drums in a band in an event on last week where we backed up Marshall Tucker band, we played some blue some still in my mind so I'll stand up by just saying baby we were born to run. Brian?

headline: American Electric Power Co., Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good money everyone. I'll take us through second quarter year-to-date financial results, provide our latest insight an economy and finish with a review of our assistant and liquidity position. Turning to Slide 5. Operating earnings for th
componenttext:
Thank you, and good money everyone. I'll take us through second quarter year-to-date financial results, provide our latest insight an economy and finish with a review of our assistant and liquidity position. 
Turning to Slide 5. Operating earnings for the second quarter were $0.95 per share or $466 million compared to $0.88 per share, $429 million in 2015. Overall the increase in earnings was driven by a rate changes, including the reversal regulatory provision and lower O&M in our regulated utilities and higher earnings in our AEP Transmission Holdco segment. Both of which were partially offset by the expected decline in the Generation & Marketing segment. 
Earnings for the Vertically Integrated Utilities segment were $0.43 in the share our second quarter both 2016 and 2015. Lower O&M due to decreased playing outage expenses and recovery of incremental investment to serve our customers were offset by lower margins on retail sales and decreased off-system sales margin due to lower energy prices. The Transmission & Distribution Utilities segment are in $0.25 per share for the quarter up $0.09 from last year. This segments major variances included the reversal of the previous regulatory provision in Ohio adding $0.03 per share and higher margins on retail sales, which added $0.02 per share.
Other favorable drivers each adding a penny per share or rate changes, higher archive transmission revenue and lower O&M expense. Our AEP Transmission Holdco segment continues to grow, contributing $0.19 per share for the quarter and improvement of $0.06. The growth in earnings reflects our return on incremental investment and includes the impact of the annual true up the formula mechanism. That plan investment deferred taxes grew by approximately $840 million an increase of 32% since last June.
The generation in marketing segment produced our earnings of $0.09 per share down $0.07 last year. Capacity revenues were lower by $0.07 due to retirements and the transition of Ohio to full market pricing. Energy margins were lower by $0.03 per share due to power prices liquidating 18% lower than last year. 
On the positive side, the commercial organization in our competitive business performed well and wholesale trading and marketing was favorable by penny this quarter. Corporate & Other down opinion from last year due to higher O&M expense.
Let's turn to Slide 6, and I'll briefly highlight our year-to-date results. Operating results through June, operating earnings through June were $1.97 per share or $967 million compared to $2.15 per share or $1.1 billion in 2015. The details on the slide for those of you would like to, but overall the decrease in earning was driven by the expected decline in earnings Generation & Marketing segment, less favorable weather conditions in the first quarter, depressed power prices and disposition of our business last year.
These unfavorable drivers will partially offset by rate changes, the change in the effective tax rate, growth in normalize margin and increased earnings in our transmission businesses. 
Now let's take a look at Slide 7 to review normalized load performance. For both the quarterly and year-to-date comparisons, the message is the same. Our normalized retail sales were down compared to last year, because the increase in residential and commercial sales was more than offset by the drop in industrial load. And the lower rate chart normalize retail sales were down 0.04% for the quarter and 0.03% year-to-date. For both periods, the strong sales performance in our Texas territory is being offset by weakness in the Appalachian and Kentucky regions, this illustrates the benefit of geography diversity. 
Normalized residential sales in the upper left, rebounded in the second quarter and are now essentially flat compared to last year. Through the first half of 2016, our residential sales customer counts and normalized usage were all essentially flat. In the upper right, commercial sales grew by 1% for the quarter and are up 0.08% year-to-date. This growth was spread across several of our operating companies. Although, the strongest growth occurred with the utility segment. This is consistent with some of the economic data I'll share with you on the next slide.
Finally, industrial sales drop by 4% this quarter and are down 1.6% through June. The sustained drop in energy prices, weak global demand and strong dollar have combined to form a challenging environment for manufacturers. 
For the quarter, industrial sales declined in 7 of our top 10 industry sectors. The 2 sector that grew in the second quarter were Pipeline Transportation and transportation equipment manufacturing. The Petroleum & Coal Products sector was flat for the quarter.  I'll provide additional color on our industrial sales later. 
Now let's turn to Slide 8, to look at the most recent economic data for AEP service territory. Starting at the top with GDP, the estimated 1.3% growth for AEP is only 0.03% behind the U.S. The upper right chart shows that our Eastern territory is not only growing faster than our Western territory, but is now exceeding the U.S. This is not the case for our Western territory, where there is greater exposure to lower oil and gas prices. Depressed energy prices have created a noticeable in our Western footprint, while the nation benefits from lower fuel prices, AEP's regional economy supporting these shale plays on experiencing the impact of jobs. 
The chart at the bottom -- the charts at the bottom showed that employment growth for AEP it's holding steady at 1.1% but still lags the U.S. by 0.06%. It is not surprising to see job growth in AEP's Eastern territory exceeding the West given what we just discussed. 
Earlier in the presentation, I mention that our commercial sales were the strongest in our utility segment, that matches they employment data for our service territory as well. Over two thirds of all jobs added in 2016, have been in Ohio and Texas. The sector showing the strongest job growth for the quarter include construction, leisure and hospitality and education and health services. These gains were somewhat offset by the decline in natural resources and mining jobs. Today, there are over 22,000 fewer employees in that sector than last year, and approximately 15,000 of those jobs were located in our Western footprint. 
Now let's turn to Slide 9 to review our industrial sales by trend, trends by region -- I'm sorry. Over the last several years, our industrial sales growth has largely been tight to the oil and gas activity around the major cell plays. Up until this quarter, sales to the oil and gas sectors have been fairly resilient despite low energy prices. The chart in the upper left shows that the is started to turn. AEP's the industrial sales initial County this quarter actually declined by, specifically the decline is largely coming from our upstream oil and gas extraction sector, which experienced a 6% decline for the quarter. 
The map on the right identifies our coal counties shown in blue. I want to highlight these counties since we continue to see significant erosion in our industrial sales as well as customer counts in this area. In the upper left charge, our industrial sales in the coal counties were down 14% for this quarter a mobile sales to the mining sector alone were down nearly 18%. 
Lower natural gas prices, environmental the regulations, lower demand from the utility sector and as demand globally for metallurgical coal has created bad situation for Appalachian coal producers. Outside of our shale and coal counties, the rest of AEP's industrial sales were down 3.3% for the quarter. 
Now let's move on to Slide 10 to review the company's capitalization and liquidity. Our total debt to capital ratio up by during the quarter and remained healthy of 54%. Our credit metrics, FFO interest coverage and FFO to debt are solidly in the BBB and BAA one range at 5.6x and 20.2%, respectively. 
Our qualified pension funding remained unchanged for the quarter at 94%. Although plan assets increased during the quarter, so to plan liabilities due to discount rate coming in lower than assumed. During the month of June, we funded about $86 million to plan assets and amount equal to the estimated service cost for the year. 
Our funding now stands at 101%. Plan assets increased by but plan liabilities increased 3.1% due to drop in discount rates. The overall impact dropped our OPEB funding ratio by 2.9%. The estimated after-tax O&M expense for both plans this year is expected to be about $13 million.
Finally, our net liquidity stands at about $2.3 billion and is supported by our revolving credit facilities. During the second quarter, our treasury team worked with our banking partners to amend and extend our key credit facilities. We now have $3 billion facility that extends in the June of 2021, and the second $500 million facility that expires in June of 2018. This tiered structure allows maximum flexibility as we continue our strategic review of our competitive generation assets. 
Altogether, AEP's balance sheet, liquidity and credit metrics are strong and will allow us to fund our utility Operations, growth and dividends under all reasonably foreseeable conditions.
Now let's turn to Slide 11 and ramp this up so we can get to your questions. We are pleased with our earnings results for the second quarter of this year. Gains, in our wires businesses, more than offset expected decreases in our competitive businesses due to lower energy prices and deregulation in Ohio. 
As we look towards the second half of 2016, we believe that our regulatory businesses will more than offset any challenges presented by our Generation & Marketing segment giving us the confidence to reaffirm our operating earnings guidance range of $3.60 to $3.80 per share.
Finally, as Nick mentioned earlier, the strategic review of our competitive generation remains on track and we hope to have news for you in that regard either later this quarter or early next quarter. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to the operator for your questions.

componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the last 4 years have shown us a couple of things. One is, the inconsistency of load from quarter-to-quarter and obviously we have had to work through that, I think the other thing last 4 years shown us we have to adjust to it. And when you t
componenttext: Yes, I think the last 4 years have shown us a couple of things. One is, the inconsistency of load from quarter-to-quarter and obviously we have had to work through that, I think the other thing last 4 years shown us we have to adjust to it. And when you think about the levels that we have around O&M, but also we have emerging -- emerging revenue size as well. I mean the transmission continues to pick up, there is no question we will have to continue to invest in the grid and in particular transmission as well. And then we also have other investments like solar and those kinds of relationships with customers that are improving earnings as well. So I think, when you look the 4% to 6%, we're still confident the 4% to 6%. And as we go through the year, we will certainly be able to fine tune that in more detail. But I guess, the overall message is we feel like we have the ability as we've done in the last 4 years to be able to compensate for any of these issues that occur in. And there is no question, I mean, any business, any business has to adjust based upon what the sales forecast looks like, but also look at the revenue side as well and ensure they were doing everything we can do there to do its work as well. So Greg, I know, there is a lot of concern out there about a load forecast going forward, if you trended out and of course, what we do generation. But at the end of the day, we are going to adjust to it. And I think we take very seriously the consistency that we've built and maintained over the last 4 years and we don't intend on giving that up.

componenttext: No. I think,, clearly, and we are probably little more about it, because that the major part of our business is around infrastructure, infrastructure development on the transmission side, we have a huge transmission system. So we have a lot of ability to invest. But we are always looking for sources new revenue, and we see it as another tool, and the toolbox to be able to focus on in enhancements of earnings, because obviously there is near-term benefits of a the tax credits. And we are after doing that. We have, we just did a universal scale our utility scale project in Utah that hasn't been announced yet, we can't say who, but it's 20 megawatt project and then we also have several other small projects with municipalities and so forth in New York and other locations around the country and we've been doing that, and we know how to do that. What we -- what we really are focused on those, is ensuring that we do have a place to deploy our capital in the fashion and that cans certainly augment our business, but our main focus is to be focused on infrastructure what it means. And it goes beyond, it goes to relationships with customers not sort of alluded to that in my opening discussion. You have much broader relationships with some of these customers that goes beyond solar, it goes to obviously renewables but storage. We are very focused on storage aspects. We are an investor in green speed for example, integration of solar and wind but also energy storage. And you see those applications coming together from a distribution standpoint and that's going to be a huge benefit to us. So obviously, we want to be in solar business but we also want to be in the wind power, but it's really addressing tailored needs of customers focused around that customer experience. And so I mean actually fashion is coming but we'll probably be getting larger that would be good at, we will be focused on ultimately those customer experience sort of things.

headline: American Electric Power Co., Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me give you an idea my perception of the timing here. We have the framework of legislation that we are addressing with stakeholders now. And that's whether its legislators, whether it's others that are important to the discussion process, other p
componenttext: Yes, let me give you an idea my perception of the timing here. We have the framework of legislation that we are addressing with stakeholders now. And that's whether its legislators, whether it's others that are important to the discussion process, other participants in the markets, those kinds of things. We are going to focus on that between now and November. And in November, is when the Ohio legislation comes back into place, and keep in mind I'm talking about first, the first tranche of assets, this is really regarding the second tranche, which is what formerly was the PPA asset. So the first tranche moving along. It's already the trains left the station and its moving forward. The second tranche, I'm saying from restructuring standpoint we are going to go through and how the legislation, have discussions with stakeholders, get the process implies in November when Ohio the legislator comes back into session, it will be a session. So we will have to make sure that we are focused on those legislators that are still be around in the future leaders of that organization. And then that way, we can hit the ground running with legislation that's already been large and discussed in the first quarter by the first of the year. So in the first quarter you're starter starting with new legislature. I think, we're going to know quickly people open to the possibility happening or not. And at that point in time, we've already started our secondary process that I talked about are on the PPA assets getting data room ready, all that kind of stuff. And we will make a determination where we think Ohio is going to go. Ohio many people didn't make the PPA would happen in Ohio, and it did happen. And I still think there is going to be some formal restructuring in Ohio, because there has to be. But the question becomes number one, our people receptive to number 2, is the timeframe appropriate for what we are trying to achieve, the driver here will be that secondary process and we will have to get some determination as to whether the open us and the collaboration the state of Ohio would work to get something done during the of fall that. So that's where we are at. When we think about that probably is seasonal process in the first quarter of next year that we will know whether Ohio is chance moving forward with that thing or not? So that will tell us what we need to know.

componenttextpreview: I have made a very clear in the state that we are not going to invest new generation in this period until something, until something has resolved from a restructuring standpoint and enables us to invest and do it in a wise fashion. So and the legislation
componenttext: I have made a very clear in the state that we are not going to invest new generation in this period until something, until something has resolved from a restructuring standpoint and enables us to invest and do it in a wise fashion. So and the legislation includes the ability for AEP Ohio to not only transfer those assets that were under the PPA to AEP Ohio, but also to be able to have a mechanism for investment in future generation and obviously, the state of Ohio is very interested in getting natural gas going. There's a lot of discussion about there's 3 or 4 natural gas units getting inadequate of what what the Ohio load actually is. And so, there is a capacity seeing in Ohio and if Ohio wants to take advantage of an additional natural gas build-out, the additional structural -- addition such as pipeline infrastructure, electric transmission infrastructure, the economic development follow on to all of that, there is no reason for Ohio to give that up. And so there has to be a mechanism to do that. And that's what we are after.

componenttext: Well, that's not our preference, obviously. And that's going to be determined are on the second tranche of generation for sure. Our intention is to make sure that we can transfer these assets back into the large company and enable the ability for us to continue to invest in new generation in a credible fashion. And we will take a legislative mechanism to do that. And we also obviously want to make sure that we accommodate other participants in the market in same fashion and that's part of the dialogue. But those 2 things we are after .

So it's great to get that resolved and behind us, but don't expect anything like that a recurring item.

headline: American Electric Power Co., Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I'm thinking, okay, it really is more of a soaking period, because what we want to do is in November talking to the all other stakeholders and come to the legislator with what we believe is the balance package to other participants in the market c
componenttext: Yes. So I'm thinking, okay, it really is more of a soaking period, because what we want to do is in November talking to the all other stakeholders and come to the legislator with what we believe is the balance package to other participants in the market can on to as well. If we do that, then discussions we already had with legislators we are trying to get the every legislator we can that we know is going to be still be around. And then that will be sort of November, we will get our early indication of where things are going, but really nothing, I don't expect anything can't happen until the first of the year when the new legislature comes in. But obviously, we know we is coming in, so we can have that soaking period from November, December and then move that legislation forward. I know that's our aggressive, but I think what we will be looking for is really the feedback that we get in terms of not only whether it can get done are not, but in terms of timing would be important considerations for us. So I don't see legislation actually getting done until first quarter or second quarter of next year. But if we know it's coming, and we know what's then we can plan for it .
